body:
yeah the chunker was mainly to keep the surface api the same. play can configure a `bufferSize` for gzip. thus to satisfy the api I added the chunker.

> The Chunker holds back data indefinitely if the buffer is not filled.

yeah it would hold back until no data is incoming anymore, but it should still push all the data out, if the source completes.

yeah maybe it would be better to deprecate the current interface and maybe make the `bufferSize` an `Option[Int]` which does not use the chunker if no `bufferSize` is wished. (and of course remove the default `bufferSize` of `8192` in play)

> A very late second chunk will cause the delay of the first chunk's completion (when the browser completely receives the whole), if the first chunk is a script tag for the browser to eval, then the timing of the execution of that script tag is hugely delayed.

that can't happen since the play gzip flow only works on a response body: https://github.com/playframework/playframework/blob/master/web/play-filters-helpers/src/main/scala/play/filters/gzip/GzipFilter.scala#L78

unfortunatly `GzipFlow.gzip` is a public interface, which it probably should not be. since the user should just use the akka stuff directly. the gzip filter of play is mostly designed for html/css/javascript content with a "fast producer".
and btw. since it's more or less tied to the GzipFilter it needs to buffer data anyway.

> yeah the chunker was mainly to keep the surface api the same. play can configure a `bufferSize` for gzip. thus to satisfy the api I added the chunker.

Maybe that's not needed and we can just use `bufferSize = 0` for that. Another possibility would be to keep the interface but ignore the parameter for now.

@FranklinYinanDing 

> @jrudolph Maybe I understand it wrong, or something isn't right - [this line](https://github.com/playframework/playframework/pull/6813/files#diff-dc46281aa6759e9b0b71d023b83fc87aR66) uses `splitAt`, when the buffer is smaller than the `chunkSize` (say 3 vs 8192), it will still produce the entire buffer (3) and push. So if the Http.Chunked is a sequence of small chunks, Gzip is still compressing small chunks.

I think that's correct, however, `emitChunk` is only called unconditionally from `onPush`. As you noted elsewhere, `onPull` still has this precondition which will prevent sending smaller chunks:

https://github.com/playframework/playframework/blob/f6ae7c8c50556d79b95c3a42c29dd21eae3261ad/core/play-streams/src/main/scala/play/api/libs/streams/GzipFlow.scala#L43

@schmitch 

> > A very late second chunk will cause the delay of the first chunk's completion (when the browser completely receives the whole), if the first chunk is a script tag for the browser to eval, then the timing of the execution of that script tag is hugely delayed.
> 
> that can't happen since the play gzip flow only works on a response body: [https://github.com/playframework/playframework/blob/master/web/play-filters-helpers/src/main/scala/play/filters/gzip/GzipFilter.scala#L78](https://github.com/playframework/playframework/blob/master/web/play-filters-helpers/src/main/scala/play/filters/gzip/GzipFilter.scala?rgh-link-date=2020-08-11T18%3A08%3A42Z#L78)

Why not? It gets only pulled once and then the above condition prevents sending over the remaining data.

Maybe we should just fix that condition (as @FranklinYinanDing suggested elsewhere).

well if I have a script file that should be gzipped and my stream would "hang" or never complete, the browser would hang forever, since the browser parser would block the remaining execution if the script tag is not defined at the end or with `defer`.

a chunkSize of 0 would not fix that, the stream would still never complete and the browser would still wait either for 1. content-length satisfied or 2. wait for a http chunk with length zero.

Looking at the code again, you might be able to actually disable the buffer by setting the buffer size to a higher value than any of the input chunks you expect, e.g. like `Int.MaxValue`. In that case, the `splitAt` in `onPush` would always pass on all of the data it receives and no data would ever be buffered.

repository.name: playframework
repository.description: The Community Maintained High Velocity Web Framework For Java and Scala.

body: Fix in #10422 which also explicitly adds the possibility to disable the buffer with a value of `0`.
